title: TU Delft R CafÃ©
text:
Fun with R
During R CafÃ© meetings, weâ€™re trying out different tools and types of analysis. Hereâ€™s a small sample of what weâ€™ve been working on:


Code
# Load library wordcloud2
library(wordcloud2)

#Load data
wcloud_data <- readRDS(here('data', 'wcloud_data.RDS'))

# Define colors 
tud_blue<-'#00A6D6'
mycolors <- c( rep(tud_blue,6),rep('#000000',1000))

# Create a word cloud
set.seed(12345)
wordcloud2(wcloud_data, size = 0.7, color = mycolors)




Words used in IDE master theses: word cloud created with wordcloud2 package




Code
# Load networkD3 package
library(networkD3)
library(igraph)

# Load data 
network <- readRDS(here('data', 'network.RDS'))

# Create networkD3 object.
network_D3 <- igraph_to_networkD3(g = network)

# Define node size.
network_D3$nodes$size <- 100* V(network)$degree

# Degine color group (I will explore this feature later).
network_D3$nodes$group <- 1

# Define edges width. 
network_D3$links$value <- 20*E(network)$width

# Define colours
ColourScale <- 'd3.scaleOrdinal()
            .domain(["lions", "tigers"])
           .range(["#00A6D6", "#694489"]);'

# Plot
forceNetwork(
  Links = network_D3$links, 
  Nodes = network_D3$nodes, 
  Source = 'source', 
  Target = 'target',
  NodeID = 'name',
  Group = 'group', 
  opacity = 0.9,
  Value = 'value',
  Nodesize = 'size', 
  # We input a JavaScript function.
  fontSize = 7,
  zoom = TRUE, 
  opacityNoHover = 1,
  fontFamily = "sans-serif",
  linkColour = "black",
  colourScale = JS(ColourScale)
)




Connections between words in IDE master theses: bigram count network created with networkD3 package




Code
# Load library wordcloud2
library(dygraphs)
library(quantmod) # API to get stock data

#Load data of TESLA stock
TSLA <- getSymbols("TSLA", env=NULL)

#Load data of AMZN stock
AMZN <- getSymbols("AMZN", env=NULL)
# create new df with Amazon and Tesla data
stocks <- cbind(AMZN[,2:4], TSLA[,2:4])


# Define colors 
tud_cols<- c('#00A6D6', '#EC6842', '#0C2340', '#FFB81C' )
tud_cols2<- c('#00A6D6', '#00B8C8', '#0C2340', '#0076C2' )


# Create a dygraph
dygraph(stocks) %>%
  dySeries(c("AMZN.Low", "AMZN.Close",
             "AMZN.High"), label = "AMZN") %>%
  dySeries(c("TSLA.Low", "TSLA.Close",
             "TSLA.High"), label = "TSLA") %>% 
  dyRangeSelector() %>%
  dyOptions(colors = tud_cols2[c(1,3)]) %>%
  dyAxis("x", drawGrid = FALSE) 




Amazon and Tesla Share Prices with dygraphs package

title: TU Delft R CafÃ©
text:
Subscribe
To stay informed about upcoming events, please subscribe to our mailing list.

Code







Congratulations to the winners of the first R CafÃ© Plot-a-thon, Rodrigo Revilla Llaca, Claudiu Forgaci, and Yiyuan Zou!









Note



Winner will have their data visualization featured on the 4TU.ResearchData repository website!! 






Showcase event agenda






Data visualisation challenge timeline



InfoScheduleShowcase event



Whatâ€™s the challenge?
In this thrilling challenge, you will dive into the world of statistics from the 4TU.ResearchData repository. Once you register, weâ€™ll provide instructions on how to access the data and submit your work.


How to participate?
The tool of choice for this challenge is R! You must upload your visualizations along with the R code that brought them to life, accompanied by a brief description of your project. The rest is limited only by your imagination!


Whenâ€™s the deadline?






Submission deadline



9th October 2023, 12PM


Youâ€™ll have two weeks to submit your visualizations before the showcase event on October 11th from 3:00 PM to 6:30 PM. During this event, youâ€™ll present your work, and weâ€™ll feature an engaging keynote speech while announcing the challenge winners!


Where do you work?
You can craft your visualizations at your own pace and in your own space. However, the showcase event, where you present your work will be hosted in the inviting Orange Room at the TU Delft Library.


Why join?
There are plenty of reasons to jump aboard:
Data visualization with R is fun! Youâ€™ll learn, and youâ€™ll help others learn too! The winner will have their visualization featured on the 4TUResearchData repository website. There are additional exciting prizes up for grabs!


What are the prizes?



Place
Prize




1st Place
â‚¬300 cash prize


2nd Place
â‚¬200 cash prize


3rd Place
â‚¬100 cash prize


Audience Pick
â‚¬200 cash prize






Need Help?
Should you encounter any challenges during the competition, there are numerous ways to ask for help.

Join self-help MS Teams channel
If youâ€™re stuck with a data visualization channel, post your question in the Plot-a-thon self-help Channel, for other participants and organizers to answer. Like that we learn together!


Drop by online info session
If you would like to meet us and ask questions live, join the Q&A drop-in session online. The session will take place on Wednesday, 27th September, 12:45 - 13:45.


Send us an email
If you have questions about the challenge or organization, you can always reach out to us at rcafe-lib@tudelft.nl for support!




Grading Criteria
Here are the main criteria we will use to grade the data visualizations.










criterion/score
0
1
2
3




information
The information on the visualisation is not accurate. It is unclear what the visualisation is supposed to depict.
The information in the visualisation is mostly accurate and can be fully understood with the aid of a presentation.
The information on the visualisation is accurate and easily understood without additional information from the creator. Labels, legends, and axes are clearly labeled.



visual appeal
Thatâ€™s niceâ€¦
Not bad!
Ooooh pretty!
ðŸ¤©ðŸ¤©ðŸ¤©


analysis
Limited data wrangling. No comments provided in code.
Good use of data wrangling to access additional trends in the data. Limited comments provided.
Great use of data wrangling to access information within the dataset. Great use of comments to guide the reader through the code



reproducibility
Visualisation required more than three interventions to reproduce.
Visualisation reproducible with two or three interventions.
Visualisation reproducible with only a single intervention.
Fully reproducible with no intervention. Works on Linux (Ubuntu), MacOS, and Windows.





Whatâ€™s next?
After the submission, you are invited to join our grand finale - the Showcase Event, where we invite you to present your work and to join the award ceremony. Please remember to save the date on Wednesday, 11th October, 3PM at Orange Room, TU Delft Library.




Detailed timeline







Date
Event




01/09 - 24/09
registration for the event is open*


25/09
dataset with the instructions is sent out to the participants


27/09, 12:45PM
online info drop-in session about the data and the challenge


09/10, 12PM
deadline for work submission


11/10 , 3PM
Showcase Event and Award Ceremony Starts



* You will also be able to register after this time, but you will have less time for the challenge.



Showcase agenda
All the participants of the Plot-a-thon are invited to participate in the Showcase event. During this event, youâ€™ll present your work, and weâ€™ll feature an engaging keynote speech while announcing the challenge winners!

Date: Wednesday, 11th October 2023
Time: 3PM â€“ 6:30PM CEST
Place: TU Delft Library, Orange Room


Keynote speech (3:00 PM - 3:20 PM)
Short keynote speech about data visualisations in R.


Plots presentations (3:20 PM - 4:00 PM)
Participants will shortly present their visualizations.


Coffee break (4:00 PM - 4:15 PM)
During the break we will vote for our favorite visualizations!


Awards Ceremony (4:15 PM - 4:30 PM)
Announcement of the jury pick for the 1st, 2nd and 3rd place. We will also reveal the audience pick winner!


Meet & mingle (4:30 PM - 6:30 PM)
Networking event




The first edition of the R CafÃ© Plot-a-thon was a success! The event kicked off with a keynote lecture by Roel Janssen on some of the quirks of the R programming language, followed by presentations by each of the participants.
Prizes were awarded to the winners and the day was wrapped-up with a networking event and a lot of R-talk!
Read more about the showcase event on the 4TU community website.

Winning submissions
ðŸ¥‡ 1st

ðŸ¥ˆ 2nd

ðŸ¥‰ 3rd



Event gallery

title: PLOT-A-THON
text:
About Plot-a-thon
Are you venturing into the world of R programming and seeking a challenge to elevate your skills? Perhaps you find yourself finetuning your data visualizations a tad too often? Do you yearn to express your creativity while unraveling dataâ€™s mysteries?
Read about the first TU Delft R CafÃ© Plot-a-thon: a data visualization challenge!

Who can participate?
The event is dedicated to the TU Delft community. So if you study or work at TU Delft, youâ€™re welcome to participate! The competition is open to R users of all proficiency levels!
You can register individually or as part of a group. If you prefer joining a group but donâ€™t have one in mind, donâ€™t worryâ€”we can match you with other solo R enthusiasts searching for their pack!


Past events
October 2023

Code





How big should the groups be?
There is no limit to the group size.


Can I skip the Showcase event?
At least one person from the group needs to be present at the Showcase event to present your work. Also, you wouldnâ€™t like to miss it!


I have just started to learn R. Can I still join?
Sure! You will learn plenty from the challenge, and we will assist you once you get stuck!


Will you provide food and drinks during the event?
Yes! The refreshments will be provided! We also have cool goodie-packs ready for you!


How will my work be assessed?
The data visualizations will be assessed by independent judges, using a number of assessment criteria, e.g.Â data analysis, visual design, reproducibility. The full grading rubric will be shared with with you together with the data visualization assignment.
